elements.content: Separation of ethylene (C2H4) from ethane (C2H6) through one step is desirable but challenging in view of their similar sizes and physical properties. Introduction of pore partition agents into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) endows materials with multivariate porous environments for gas adsorption and separation. Here, we report a novel microporous boron imidazolate framework (BIF-108-Zn) that integrates both organic ligands and extra-framework species as pore partition agents to divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. This structure possesses a high pore volume with a reduced pore size and a functionalized pore surface to realize preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4. Dynamic breakthrough measurements demonstrated that BIF-108-Zn can directly produce polymer-grade C2H4 with a productivity of 0.69 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4. Furthermore, the relatively low isosteric enthalpy value endows it with good regenerability and high stability, as verified by multiple adsorption separation tests.
elements.clean_text: Separation of ethylene (C2H4) from ethane (C2H6) through one step is desirable but challenging in view of their similar sizes and physical properties. Introduction of pore partition agents into metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) endows materials with multivariate porous environments for gas adsorption and separation. Here, we report a novel microporous boron imidazolate framework (BIF-108-Zn) that integrates both organic ligands and extra-framework species as pore partition agents to divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. This structure possesses a high pore volume with a reduced pore size and a functionalized pore surface to realize preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4. Dynamic breakthrough measurements demonstrated that BIF-108-Zn can directly produce polymer-grade C2H4 with a productivity of 0.69 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4. Furthermore, the relatively low isosteric enthalpy value endows it with good regenerability and high stability, as verified by multiple adsorption separation tests.

elements.content: Ethylene (C2H4) is the most important raw material in petrochemical industries. Each year, more than 170 million tons of C2H4 are produced by steam cracking or thermal decomposition of ethane (C2H6), in which the C2H6 residue inevitably coexists as a contaminant and needs to be removed to purify C2H4. Currently, industrial technologies for separation of C2H4 from C2H6 mainly rely on cryogenic high-pressure distillation, which suffers from intensive energy consumption and pollution. Therefore, separation technologies at ambient temperature and pressure are highly desirable to save energy. Adsorbent-based separation has been considered as the most promising methodology to replace the cryogenic distillation. Compared with traditional adsorbents (such as zeolites, alumina, and carbon-based materials), porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are expected to be the most promising candidate for the C2H6/C2H4 separation for their designable structures and pore surfaces, including the ease of introducing open metal sites (OMSs) and functional groups. Because of the stronger interactions between unsaturated CC bonds and the functional pore surface, C2H4 is usually preferentially captured. Although excellent adsorption separation performances have been achieved, it is still a quite energy-intensive process because further desorption of C2H4 is necessary in order to get high-quality C2H4. Furthermore, the OMSs in MOFs constructed by these strategies are usually suffering from poisoning in the presence of water vapor. By this token, it is more economical and practical to develop C2H6-selective adsorbents to produce high-purity C2H4 directly. Owing to their similar physicochemical properties and sizes, the adsorbents with preferred C2H6 adsorption over C2H4 are scarce.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ethylene (C2H4) is the most important raw material in petrochemical industries. Each year, more than 170 million tons of C2H4 are produced by steam cracking or thermal decomposition of ethane (C2H6), in which the C2H6 residue inevitably coexists as a contaminant and needs to be removed to purify C2H4. Currently, industrial technologies for separation of C2H4 from C2H6 mainly rely on cryogenic high-pressure distillation, which suffers from intensive energy consumption and pollution. Therefore, separation technologies at ambient temperature and pressure are highly desirable to save energy. Adsorbent-based separation has been considered as the most promising methodology to replace the cryogenic distillation. Compared with traditional adsorbents (such as zeolites, alumina, and carbon-based materials), porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are expected to be the most promising candidate for the C2H6/C2H4 separation for their designable structures and pore surfaces, including the ease of introducing open metal sites (OMSs) and functional groups. Because of the stronger interactions between unsaturated CC bonds and the functional pore surface, C2H4 is usually preferentially captured. Although excellent adsorption separation performances have been achieved, it is still a quite energy-intensive process because further desorption of C2H4 is necessary in order to get high-quality C2H4. Furthermore, the OMSs in MOFs constructed by these strategies are usually suffering from poisoning in the presence of water vapor. By this token, it is more economical and practical to develop C2H6-selective adsorbents to produce high-purity C2H4 directly. Owing to their similar physicochemical properties and sizes, the adsorbents with preferred C2H6 adsorption over C2H4 are scarce.

elements.content: In this context, some pioneering contributions have been made with respect to such an unusual adsorption behavior. However, rational design strategies for C2H6-selective adsorbents remain a big challenge. To design MOFs with the preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4, the key point is to tune the pore geometry and host–guest interactions. For this target, pore space partition (PSP) is one powerful strategy, which has achieved great success in gas storage and separation. A characteristic feature of PSP is the division of a large cage or a channel space into multiple domains to better fit gas molecules for efficient interaction and capture. The key to the development of such a strategy is the use of a pore partition agent whose symmetry and size match well with the parent framework. The first example of PSP was reported with extra-framework species located at the pore center as a partition agent, which later expanded to include presynthesized organic molecules and metal–triazole complexes. Recently, many new pore-partitioned materials with organic ligands or metal–organic clusters as partition agents have been reported, which exhibit excellent performances in the storage and separation of CO2 and C2H2. However, the use of the PSP strategy for C2H6/C2H4 separation has not yet been reported. In principle, it would be an effective construction strategy to combine both extra-framework species and organic ligands as partition agents in one PSP structure to tune both chemical and structural properties for better fitting C2H6 molecules.
elements.clean_text: In this context, some pioneering contributions have been made with respect to such an unusual adsorption behavior. However, rational design strategies for C2H6-selective adsorbents remain a big challenge. To design MOFs with the preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4, the key point is to tune the pore geometry and host-guest interactions. For this target, pore space partition (PSP) is one powerful strategy, which has achieved great success in gas storage and separation. A characteristic feature of PSP is the division of a large cage or a channel space into multiple domains to better fit gas molecules for efficient interaction and capture. The key to the development of such a strategy is the use of a pore partition agent whose symmetry and size match well with the parent framework. The first example of PSP was reported with extra-framework species located at the pore center as a partition agent, which later expanded to include presynthesized organic molecules and metal-triazole complexes. Recently, many new pore-partitioned materials with organic ligands or metal-organic clusters as partition agents have been reported, which exhibit excellent performances in the storage and separation of CO2 and C2H2. However, the use of the PSP strategy for C2H6/C2H4 separation has not yet been reported. In principle, it would be an effective construction strategy to combine both extra-framework species and organic ligands as partition agents in one PSP structure to tune both chemical and structural properties for better fitting C2H6 molecules.

elements.content: In this work, we report one microporous boron imidazolate framework (DMA) n/3[Zn­(4-PyC)­(BH­(2-mim)3)1/3] n (BIF-108-Zn; 2-mim = 2-methylimidazole, 4-PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylate, and DMA = dimethylammonium ((CH3)2NH2 +), generated through in situ solvolysis of DMF), which integrates both the boron imidazolate ligand of BH­(2-mim)3)− and extra-framework cations of DMA as pore space partition agents to divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. Due to multivariate pore space partition effects, BIF-108-Zn exhibits a high pore volume with a reduced pore size and a functionalized pore surface for C2H6/C2H4 separation. The insertion of BH­(mim)3 – ligands increases the framework connectivity to enhance the stability of the parent framework. The insertion of guest cations can further reduce the pore size and optimize the pore environment for fitting C2H6 molecules. As expected, the partitioned pore space within the activated BIF-108-Zn indeed leads to preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4. Dynamic adsorption breakthrough experiments revealed that BIF-108-Zn can selectively capture C2H6 from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4 to directly produce polymer-grade C2H4 with a high productivity of 0.69 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar. To the best of our knowledge, BIF-108-Zn is the first PSP MOF that integrates both an organic ligand and extra-framework species as pore partition agents in one structure for C2H4 separation from an C2H6/C2H4 mixture.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report one microporous boron imidazolate framework (DMA) n/3[Zn(4-PyC)(BH(2-mim)3)1/3] n  (BIF-108-Zn; 2-mim = 2-methylimidazole, 4-PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylate, and DMA = dimethylammonium ((CH3)2NH2 +), generated through in situ solvolysis of DMF), which integrates both the boron imidazolate ligand of BH(2-mim)3)- and extra-framework cations of DMA as pore space partition agents to divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. Due to multivariate pore space partition effects, BIF-108-Zn exhibits a high pore volume with a reduced pore size and a functionalized pore surface for C2H6/C2H4 separation. The insertion of BH(mim)3 - ligands increases the framework connectivity to enhance the stability of the parent framework. The insertion of guest cations can further reduce the pore size and optimize the pore environment for fitting C2H6 molecules. As expected, the partitioned pore space within the activated BIF-108-Zn indeed leads to preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4. Dynamic adsorption breakthrough experiments revealed that BIF-108-Zn can selectively capture C2H6 from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4 to directly produce polymer-grade C2H4 with a high productivity of 0.69 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar. To the best of our knowledge, BIF-108-Zn is the first PSP MOF that integrates both an organic ligand and extra-framework species as pore partition agents in one structure for C2H4 separation from an C2H6/C2H4 mixture.

elements.content: Colorless crystals of BIF-108-Zn were obtained through a solvothermal reaction between KBH­(2-mim)3, 4-PyC, and zinc acetate in a mixed solution of H2O, isopropyl alcohol, and dimethylformamide (DMF) at 80 °C for 3 days. BIF-108-Zn possesses a three-dimensional anionic framework [Zn­(4-PyC)­(BH­(2-mim)3)1/3] n n/3–, and (CH3)2NH2 + cations reside in its pores. An X-ray single-crystal diffraction experiment revealed that BIF-108-Zn crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅ (Table S1). The asymmetric unit of BIF-108-Zn includes one crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ion, one 4-pyrazolecarboxylate ligand, one-third BH­(2-mim)3 – ligand, and one-third (CH3)2NH2 + cation. In this unit, each Zn­(II) is 4-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms (two pyrazole nitrogens from two PyC ligands and one imidazolate nitrogen from the BH­(2-mim)3 – ligand) and one oxygen atom from the carboxylate group of the 4-PyC ligand, giving rise to a tetrahedral geometry (a). Two Zn­(II) ions are bridged by two 4-PyC ligands using the pyrazole nitrogen to form a dimeric unit. These dimeric units act as 4-connected nodes linked by four 4-PyC ligands to form a 3D framework with 1D hexagonally shaped channels with C 3 symmetry along the c-axis (b). The most fascinating feature is that the tridentate BH­(2-mim)3 – ligands locate at the centers of the hexagonal channels through coordinating with three Zn­(II) ions on the wall of the channel at the same height because the symmetry and size match well with each other. Without considering the BH­(mim)3 – ligands, the whole framework of BIF-108-Zn can be simplified to a typical 4-connected NbO topology with the Schläfli symbol of (64,82) (b and Figure S1). The insertion of BH­(mim)3 – ligands completes the tetrahedral coordination of Zn­(II) ions and increases the framework from 4-connected to a (4,6)-connected network, resulting in a robust partitioned NbO (PNbO) net. Although a number of lightweight boron imidazolate frameworks have been prepared by utilizing the BH­(mim)3 – ligand, it is the first time to use it as a pore partition agent.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Colorless crystals of BIF-108-Zn were obtained through a solvothermal reaction between KBH(2-mim)3, 4-PyC, and zinc acetate in a mixed solution of H2O, isopropyl alcohol, and dimethylformamide (DMF) at 80 °C for 3 days. BIF-108-Zn possesses a three-dimensional anionic framework [Zn(4-PyC)(BH(2-mim)3)1/3] n   n/3-, and (CH3)2NH2 + cations reside in its pores. An X-ray single-crystal diffraction experiment revealed that BIF-108-Zn crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅  (Table S1). The asymmetric unit of BIF-108-Zn includes one crystallographically independent Zn(II) ion, one 4-pyrazolecarboxylate ligand, one-third BH(2-mim)3 - ligand, and one-third (CH3)2NH2 + cation. In this unit, each Zn(II) is 4-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms (two pyrazole nitrogens from two PyC ligands and one imidazolate nitrogen from the BH(2-mim)3 - ligand) and one oxygen atom from the carboxylate group of the 4-PyC ligand, giving rise to a tetrahedral geometry (a). Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by two 4-PyC ligands using the pyrazole nitrogen to form a dimeric unit. These dimeric units act as 4-connected nodes linked by four 4-PyC ligands to form a 3D framework with 1D hexagonally shaped channels with C 3 symmetry along the c-axis (b). The most fascinating feature is that the tridentate BH(2-mim)3 - ligands locate at the centers of the hexagonal channels through coordinating with three Zn(II) ions on the wall of the channel at the same height because the symmetry and size match well with each other. Without considering the BH(mim)3 - ligands, the whole framework of BIF-108-Zn can be simplified to a typical 4-connected NbO topology with the Schläfli symbol of (64,82) (b and Figure S1). The insertion of BH(mim)3 - ligands completes the tetrahedral coordination of Zn(II) ions and increases the framework from 4-connected to a (4,6)-connected network, resulting in a robust partitioned NbO (PNbO) net. Although a number of lightweight boron imidazolate frameworks have been prepared by utilizing the BH(mim)3 - ligand, it is the first time to use it as a pore partition agent.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment and the formation of dimeric metal units and (b) view of the 3D framework of BIF-108-Zn before and after partition.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment and the formation of dimeric metal units and (b) view of the 3D framework of BIF-108-Zn before and after partition.

elements.content: The most dramatic impact of the BH­(mim)3 – ligand insertion occurs on the pore size and pore geometry. The original continuous 1D hexagonal channel with an aperture size of 9.5 × 9.5 Å2 in the NbO net is divided into an infinite number of small finite segments in the PNbO network (a). These segments are about 6.1 or 7.0 Å in length for BIF-108-Zn with potential for enhanced confinement effects and multiple-point adsorption. In addition to the pore space partition effect, the integration of the BH­(mim)3 – ligand may be particularly helpful in the formation of a charged framework. Therefore, the associated extra-framework cations ((CH3)2NH2 +) are included into the pore space of the anionic framework (b). Furthermore, these extra-framework cations act as soft pore space agents to further divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. As shown in c, the (CH3)2NH2 + cation forms one weak hydrogen bond with the O atom in the skeleton. The distance from the mass center of the (CH3)2NH2 + cation to the metal atoms of the aperture ranges from 5.0 to 9.0 Å. It is different from the pore space agent of BH­(mim)3 – binding by coordination bonds, and the position of these (CH3)2NH2 + cations can be slightly changed during the gas adsorption and desorption process. Therefore, the BIF-108-Zn successfully integrates soft and robust pore space partition to one framework with multivariate environments for the optimization of gas adsorption and separation.

The original continuous 1D hexagonal channel with an aperture size of 9.5 × 9.5 Å2 in the NbO net is divided into an infinite number of small finite segments in the PNbO network (a). These segments are about 6.1 or 7.0 Å in length for BIF-108-Zn with potential for enhanced confinement effects and multiple-point adsorption. In addition to the pore space partition effect, the integration of the BH(mim)3 - ligand may be particularly helpful in the formation of a charged framework. Therefore, the associated extra-framework cations ((CH3)2NH2 +) are included into the pore space of the anionic framework (b).  Furthermore, these extra-framework cations act as soft pore space agents to further divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. As shown in c, the (CH3)2NH2 + cation forms one weak hydrogen bond with the O atom in the skeleton. The distance from the mass center of the (CH3)2NH2 + cation to the metal atoms of the aperture ranges from 5.0 to 9.0 Å. It is different from the pore space agent of BH(mim)3 - binding by coordination bonds, and the position of these (CH3)2NH2 + cations can be slightly changed during the gas adsorption and desorption process. Therefore, the BIF-108-Zn successfully integrates soft and robust pore space partition to one framework with multivariate environments for the optimization of gas adsorption and separation.

elements.content: (a) View of the 1D hexagonal channel partitioned by the BH­(mim)3 – ligand, (b) (CH3)2NH2 + cations further dividing the interconnected channels into isolated cages, and (c) weak hydrogen bonding between guest cations of (CH3)2NH2 + and the skeleton framework.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of the 1D hexagonal channel partitioned by the BH(mim)3 - ligand, (b) (CH3)2NH2 + cations further dividing the interconnected channels into isolated cages, and (c) weak hydrogen bonding between guest cations of (CH3)2NH2 + and the skeleton framework.

elements.content: The phase purity and the crystalline framework structure of BIF-108-Zn were determined by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and in situ variable-temperature PXRD tests showed that BIF-108-Zn collapses at about 200 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figures S3 and S4). On the other hand, BIF-108-Zn exhibited good chemical stability under water and different organic solvent environments, such as ethanol, acetone, and tetrahydrofuran (a). The framework can also retain its structural integrity after soaking in acidic/basic (1 ≤ pH ≤ 12) aqueous solutions at room temperature for 24 h traced by PXRD tests (b). Note that the moderate thermal stability and extraordinary chemical stability of BIF-108-Zn can be partly explained by the charged framework property and the increased rigidity of the pore space partition of the structure.
elements.clean_text: The phase purity and the crystalline framework structure of BIF-108-Zn were determined by powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and in situ variable-temperature PXRD tests showed that BIF-108-Zn collapses at about 200 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figures S3 and S4). On the other hand, BIF-108-Zn exhibited good chemical stability under water and different organic solvent environments, such as ethanol, acetone, and tetrahydrofuran (a). The framework can also retain its structural integrity after soaking in acidic/basic (1 ≤ pH ≤ 12) aqueous solutions at room temperature for 24 h traced by PXRD tests (b). Note that the moderate thermal stability and extraordinary chemical stability of BIF-108-Zn can be partly explained by the charged framework property and the increased rigidity of the pore space partition of the structure.

elements.content: (a) Solvent stability of BIF-108-Zn, including water and seven different organic solvents, (b) chemical stability by soaking BIF-108-Zn crystals in different pH solvents, (c) N2 adsorption at 77 K with the inset of the pore size distribution, and (d) CO2 adsorption at 273 and 298 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Solvent stability of BIF-108-Zn, including water and seven different organic solvents, (b) chemical stability by soaking BIF-108-Zn crystals in different pH solvents, (c) N2 adsorption at 77 K with the inset of the pore size distribution, and (d) CO2 adsorption at 273 and 298 K.

elements.content: To investigate the permanent porosity of BIF-108-Zn, the as-synthesized samples were activated by solvent exchange in ethanol for a week and then degassed at 80 °C under high vacuum prior to the measurement. The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K showed a type-I adsorption isotherm behavior with a maximum uptake of 255 cm3/g, which is characteristic of microporous materials and consistent with the crystal structure (c). The corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of BIF-108-Zn were 708 m2/g and 0.39 cm3/g, respectively. The pore size distribution derived from the NLDFT model-based analysis upon the corresponding N2 sorption isotherms gave the peak position at 6.4 Å, which is close to the data from the crystal structure. Moreover, the CO2 isotherms were measured up to 1 bar at different temperatures. BIF-108-Zn exhibited reversible CO2 adsorption with uptake values of 87.0 cm3/g (3.8 mmol/g) at 273 K and 64.4 cm3/g (2.9 mmol/g) at 298 K (d), which are comparable to some of the best performing metal–azolate frameworks (e.g., 5A@ZIF-8, 3.0 mmol/g; MAF-23, 3.3 mmol/g; MAF-25, 5.2 mmol/g; MAF-26, 3.8 mmol/g). From the above results, it can be concluded that the pore space of BIF-108-Zn can be finely tuned through a soft–robust combination pore space partition strategy, leading to a high pore volume with a small pore size.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the permanent porosity of BIF-108-Zn, the as-synthesized samples were activated by solvent exchange in ethanol for a week and then degassed at 80 °C under high vacuum prior to the measurement. The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K showed a type-I adsorption isotherm behavior with a maximum uptake of 255 cm3/g, which is characteristic of microporous materials and consistent with the crystal structure (c). The corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of BIF-108-Zn were 708 m2/g and 0.39 cm3/g, respectively. The pore size distribution derived from the NLDFT model-based analysis upon the corresponding N2 sorption isotherms gave the peak position at 6.4 Å, which is close to the data from the crystal structure. Moreover, the CO2 isotherms were measured up to 1 bar at different temperatures. BIF-108-Zn exhibited reversible CO2 adsorption with uptake values of 87.0 cm3/g (3.8 mmol/g) at 273 K and 64.4 cm3/g (2.9 mmol/g) at 298 K (d), which are comparable to some of the best performing metal-azolate frameworks (e.g., 5A@ZIF-8, 3.0 mmol/g; MAF-23, 3.3 mmol/g; MAF-25, 5.2 mmol/g; MAF-26, 3.8 mmol/g). From the above results, it can be concluded that the pore space of BIF-108-Zn can be finely tuned through a soft-robust combination pore space partition strategy, leading to a high pore volume with a small pore size.

elements.content: The permanent microporosity and desirable pore size motivated us to explore its utility as an adsorbent for C2H6/C2H4 separation. Single-component adsorption isotherms for C2H6 and C2H4 were measured at 273 and 298 K, and both reveal type-I isotherms (a). The adsorption amount of C2H6 (78.7 cm3/g) was lower than that of C2H4 (88.6 cm3/g) at 1 bar and 273 K, whereas at 298 K, the uptakes were almost the same (62.7 cm3/g for C2H6 and 61.6 cm3/g for C2H4). More importantly, the uptake isotherm of C2H6 revealed a steeper slope than that of C2H4 under low pressures (b), indicating the preference of BIF-108-Zn for C2H6 over C2H4. The unique adsorption characteristic can be explained by the window size and the charged microporous environment of the cage. Furthermore, the isosteric enthalpies (Q st) of adsorption were calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation, giving 22.5 kJ/mol for C2H6 at zero coverage, slightly higher than the value of 21.2 kJ/mol for C2H4 (Figures S5–S7). Q st values were in agreement with the sorption isotherms. Note that a relatively low isosteric enthalpy value means a relatively low energy consumption for absorbent regeneration. The above results suggested that BIF-108-Zn might be a potential candidate for the separation of C2H6 and C2H4. To estimate the adsorption selectivity, the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) was employed from single-component experimental adsorption isotherms (c and Figures S8 and S9). The selectivity value of C2H6 over C2H4 was 1.37 for a binary gas mixture (50:50 v/v) at room temperature and 100 kPa, which is lower than that of Fe2(O2)­(dobdc) (4.4) while being comparable with other reported classic materials (NPU-1/2/3 (1.32/1.52/3.21), UiO-66 (1.8), IRMOF-8 (1.8), and UTSA-35 (1.4)).

Single-component adsorption isotherms for C2H6 and C2H4 were measured at 273 and 298 K, and both reveal type-I isotherms (a). The adsorption amount of C2H6 (78.7 cm3/g) was lower than that of C2H4 (88.6 cm3/g) at 1 bar and 273 K, whereas at 298 K, the uptakes were almost the same (62.7 cm3/g for C2H6 and 61.6 cm3/g for C2H4). More importantly, the uptake isotherm of C2H6 revealed a steeper slope than that of C2H4 under low pressures (b), indicating the preference of BIF-108-Zn for C2H6 over C2H4. The selectivity value of C2H6 over C2H4 was 1.37 for a binary gas mixture (50:50 v/v) at room temperature and 100 kPa, which is lower than that of Fe2(O2)(dobdc) (4.4) while being comparable with other reported classic materials (NPU-1/2/3 (1.32/1.52/3.21), UiO-66 (1.8), IRMOF-8 (1.8), and UTSA-35 (1.4)).

elements.content: (a) Adsorption isotherms of BIF-108-Zn for C2H6 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K (filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively), (b) enlargement of adsorption isotherms from 0 to 200 mmHg at 298 K, (c) predicted mixture adsorption isotherms and selectivity of BIF-108-Zn by the IAST method for a binary gas mixture (50/50 C2H6/C2H4), (d,e) breakthrough experimental curves and three cycles for the C2H6/C2H4 (50/50) mixture at 298 K and 1 bar on BIF-108-Zn, and (f) in situ FTIR spectra of BIF-108-Zn with an increase in the C2H6 concentration.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Adsorption isotherms of BIF-108-Zn for C2H6 and C2H4 at 273 and 298 K (filled and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively), (b) enlargement of adsorption isotherms from 0 to 200 mmHg at 298 K, (c) predicted mixture adsorption isotherms and selectivity of BIF-108-Zn by the IAST method for a binary gas mixture (50/50 C2H6/C2H4), (d,e) breakthrough experimental curves and three cycles for the C2H6/C2H4 (50/50) mixture at 298 K and 1 bar on BIF-108-Zn, and (f) in situ FTIR spectra of BIF-108-Zn with an increase in the C2H6 concentration.

elements.content: To evaluate the actual separation ability, dynamic adsorption breakthrough experiments were also carried out in a packed column of the activated BIF-108-Zn for C2H6/C2H4 (50/50, v/v) binary mixtures. The breakthrough data reveal that the complete separation of C2H6 from C2H4 can be effectively achieved by BIF-108-Zn under ambient conditions. C2H4 first broke through the adsorption bed at ca. 45 min, to give a desirable polymer-grade (>99.9%) C2H4 at the outlet (d). After a certain time, C2H6 broke through the column, and the outlet gas stream reached the equilibrium. According to the breakthrough data, the adsorption capacity of pure C2H4 in BIF-108-Zn during the breakthrough process was calculated to be 0.69 mmol/g, which is comparable with some reported excellent materials (Fe2(O2)­(dobdc), 0.79 mmol/g; MAF-49, 0.28 mmol/g; Azole-Th-1, 0.68 mmol/g, Table S2). Meanwhile, the selectivity was calculated to be 1.21, indicating a moderate separation ability under dynamic separation conditions. Furthermore, three cycle breakthrough experiments were conducted under the same conditions to test the recyclability of BIF-108-Zn (e). The breakthrough time interval remained almost unchanged, meaning no noticeable loss in the separation capacity. In addition, the PXRD pattern of our sample collected after the breakthrough experiments was also consistent with the PXRD pattern before the breakthrough (Figure S10), which further verified its good regenerability and high stability. To understand the origin of the selective adsorption to C2H6 over C2H4, in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) studies were carried out by exposing the activated BIF-108-Zn to C2H6 and C2H4. The FTIR spectrum of BIF-108-Zn exhibited strong peaks at 2950 and 2888 cm–1 in an C2H6 atmosphere (Figure S11) and 3100 and 2987 cm–1 in an C2H4 atmosphere (Figure S12), which are assigned to gaseous or physisorbed C2H6 and C2H4, respectively. Notably, two new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm–1 appeared when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H6 atmosphere, and their intensity increased with an increase in the C2H6 concentration (f). However, new peaks were difficult to detect when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H4 atmosphere. The emergence of new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm–1 was attributed to the enhanced intermolecular interactions among the adsorbates (C2H6) and the weak van der Waals interactions between adsorbates and the framework of BIF-108-Zn. These observations demonstrated that the reduced pore size and the charged pore environment in BIF-108-Zn contribute to enhanced confinement effects and multisite adsorption for C2H6.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the actual separation ability, dynamic adsorption breakthrough experiments were also carried out in a packed column of the activated BIF-108-Zn for C2H6/C2H4 (50/50, v/v) binary mixtures. The breakthrough data reveal that the complete separation of C2H6 from C2H4 can be effectively achieved by BIF-108-Zn under ambient conditions. C2H4 first broke through the adsorption bed at ca. 45 min, to give a desirable polymer-grade (>99.9%) C2H4 at the outlet (d). After a certain time, C2H6 broke through the column, and the outlet gas stream reached the equilibrium. According to the breakthrough data, the adsorption capacity of pure C2H4 in BIF-108-Zn during the breakthrough process was calculated to be 0.69 mmol/g, which is comparable with some reported excellent materials (Fe2(O2)(dobdc), 0.79 mmol/g; MAF-49, 0.28 mmol/g; Azole-Th-1, 0.68 mmol/g, Table S2). Meanwhile, the selectivity was calculated to be 1.21, indicating a moderate separation ability under dynamic separation conditions. Furthermore, three cycle breakthrough experiments were conducted under the same conditions to test the recyclability of BIF-108-Zn (e). The breakthrough time interval remained almost unchanged, meaning no noticeable loss in the separation capacity. In addition, the PXRD pattern of our sample collected after the breakthrough experiments was also consistent with the PXRD pattern before the breakthrough (Figure S10), which further verified its good regenerability and high stability. To understand the origin of the selective adsorption to C2H6 over C2H4, in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) studies were carried out by exposing the activated BIF-108-Zn to C2H6 and C2H4. The FTIR spectrum of BIF-108-Zn exhibited strong peaks at 2950 and 2888 cm-1 in an C2H6 atmosphere (Figure S11) and 3100 and 2987 cm-1 in an C2H4 atmosphere (Figure S12), which are assigned to gaseous or physisorbed C2H6 and C2H4, respectively. Notably, two new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm-1 appeared when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H6 atmosphere, and their intensity increased with an increase in the C2H6 concentration (f). However, new peaks were difficult to detect when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H4 atmosphere. The emergence of new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm-1 was attributed to the enhanced intermolecular interactions among the adsorbates (C2H6) and the weak van der Waals interactions between adsorbates and the framework of BIF-108-Zn. These observations demonstrated that the reduced pore size and the charged pore environment in BIF-108-Zn contribute to enhanced confinement effects and multisite adsorption for C2H6.

elements.content: In summary, we have realized the first example of a pore space-partitioned MOF (BIF-108-Zn) that integrates two types of pore partition agents, including organic ligands and extra-framework species, to divide the continuous channels into an infinite number of isolated cages. A high pore volume with a reduced pore size is realized by the multivariate pore space partition effects, affording a functionalized pore environment suitable for selectively capturing C2H6 from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4. Dynamic breakthrough measurements demonstrate that BIF-108-Zn enables production of C2H4 in >99.9% purity at the ambient condition in one step. The relatively low isosteric heat ensures that BIF-108-Zn can be regenerated easily through purging over a short period time, which is desirable for low-energy-cost adsorbents. Furthermore, BIF-108-Zn is stable and shows no deficiency in multiple adsorption separations. This work demonstrates that the PSP strategy is applicable for precisely regulating MOFs’ pore interior environments for C2H6/C2H4 separation, further facilitating the rational design of porous materials for other challenging gas separations.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have realized the first example of a pore space-partitioned MOF (BIF-108-Zn) that integrates two types of pore partition agents, including organic ligands and extra-framework species, to divide the continuous channels into an infinite number of isolated cages. A high pore volume with a reduced pore size is realized by the multivariate pore space partition effects, affording a functionalized pore environment suitable for selectively capturing C2H6 from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4. Dynamic breakthrough measurements demonstrate that BIF-108-Zn enables production of C2H4 in >99.9% purity at the ambient condition in one step. The relatively low isosteric heat ensures that BIF-108-Zn can be regenerated easily through purging over a short period time, which is desirable for low-energy-cost adsorbents. Furthermore, BIF-108-Zn is stable and shows no deficiency in multiple adsorption separations. This work demonstrates that the PSP strategy is applicable for precisely regulating MOFs' pore interior environments for C2H6/C2H4 separation, further facilitating the rational design of porous materials for other challenging gas separations.

elements.content: The mixture of KBH­(2-mim)3 (0.043 g), 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (0.042 g), and zinc acetate­(0.080 g), in a water (H2O, 1 mL)/isopropyl alcohol (2 mL)/dimethylformamide (DMF, 2 mL) solution, was placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with ethanol and distilled water, the colorless crystals were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of the BIF-108-Zn Crystal

The mixture of KBH(2-mim)3 (0.043 g), 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (0.042 g), and zinc acetate(0.080 g), in a water (H2O, 1 mL)/isopropyl alcohol (2 mL)/dimethylformamide (DMF, 2 mL) solution, was placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with ethanol and distilled water, the colorless crystals were obtained.

elements.content: Before gas sorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were activated by solvent exchange in ethanol for a week and then degassed at 80 °C under high vacuum prior to the measurement. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer was used to measure single-component gas adsorption isotherms.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Component Gas Sorption Experiments

Before gas sorption experiments, the as-synthesized samples were activated by solvent exchange in ethanol for a week and then degassed at 80 °C under high vacuum prior to the measurement. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area analyzer was used to measure single-component gas adsorption isotherms.

elements.content: The adsorption enthalpy was calculated using adsorption data from different temperatures (273 and 298 K for C2H6 and 273, 283, and 298 K for C2H4). The virial equation was used to fit these data, where P is the pressure described in Pa, N is the adsorbed amount in mmol/g, T is the temperature in K, ai and bi are virial coefficients, and m and n are the number of coefficients used to describe the isotherms. ln ( P ) = ln ( N ) + ( 1 T ) ∑ i = 0 m a i × N i + ∑ j = 0 n b j × N j
elements.clean_text:
Calculations of Adsorption Isosteric Heats

The adsorption enthalpy was calculated using adsorption data from different temperatures (273 and 298 K for C2H6 and 273, 283, and 298 K for C2H4). The virial equation was used to fit these data, where P is the pressure described in Pa, N is the adsorbed amount in mmol/g, T is the temperature in K, ai  and bi  are virial coefficients, and m and n are the number of coefficients used to describe the isotherms.    ln  ( P )  = ln  ( N )  +  (   1   T   )     ∑   i = 0   m     a   i    ×   N   i   +    ∑   j = 0   n     b   j    ×   N   j

elements.content:
Then, the coverage-dependent enthalpy (Q st) was calculated by the following equation, where R is the universal gas constant. Q st = − R × ∑ i = 0 m a i × N i

C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>6</sub>/C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub> Selectivity Calculation via IAST

The ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) was used to assess C2H6/C2H4 separation performance. The isotherm data for pure C2H6 and C2H4 from 298 K were fitted using a single-site Langmuir–Freundlich (LF) model, where N and P are the adsorbed amount and pressure of component i, respectively. N = a 1 b 1 P c 1 1 + b 1 P c 1
elements.clean_text:
Then, the coverage-dependent enthalpy (Q st) was calculated by the following equation, where R is the universal gas constant.      Q   st   = - R ×    ∑   i = 0   m     a   i    ×   N   i      

C2H6/C2H4 Selectivity Calculation via IAST

The ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) was used to assess C2H6/C2H4 separation performance. The isotherm data for pure C2H6 and C2H4 from 298 K were fitted using a single-site Langmuir-Freundlich (LF) model, where N and P are the adsorbed amount and pressure of component i, respectively.    N =   a   1       b   1     P   c 1     1 +   b   1     P   c 1

elements.content: The IAST model of Myers and Prausnitz was employed for calculating the adsorption selectivity for binary mixtures of C2H6/C2H4, where xi is the mole fraction of component i in the adsorbed phase and yi is the mole fraction of component i in the bulk. S i / j = x i x j × y j y i
elements.clean_text: The IAST model of Myers and Prausnitz was employed for calculating the adsorption selectivity for binary mixtures of C2H6/C2H4, where xi  is the mole fraction of component i in the adsorbed phase and yi  is the mole fraction of component i in the bulk.      S    i  /  j    =     x   i       x   j     ×     y   j       y   i

elements.content: The breakthrough curves were recorded on a home-built setup equipped with a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer GSD320). The breakthrough experiments for the C2H6/C2H4 (50/50, v/v) mixture were carried out at a flow rate of 2 mL/min (298 K, 1 bar). An activated BIF-108-Zn powder sample (510 mg) was packed into a custom-made stainless-steel column (3.0 mm I.D. × 120 mm) under a pure He atmosphere. The flow rates of all gas mixtures were regulated by mass flow controllers. The outlet gas from the column was monitored by a mass spectrometer. Prior to breakthrough experiments, the sample was activated in situ in the adsorption bed with a vacuum pump for 12 h at 333 K. After the breakthrough experiment, the sample was regenerated in situ in the column for 12 h at 373 K. The complete breakthrough of C2H6 was determined using downstream gas composition reaching that of the feed gas. On the basis of the mass balance, the gas adsorption capacities can be determined from the following equation: q i = C i V 22.4 m × ∫ o t ( 1 − F F 0 ) d t where qi is the equilibrium adsorption capacity of gas i (mmol/g), Ci is the feed gas concentration, V is the volumetric feed flow rate (cm3/min), t is the adsorption time (min), F 0 and F refer to the inlet and outlet gas molar flow rates, and m refers to the adsorbent mass (g). The separation factor (α) of breakthrough experiments was calculated as follows: α = q A y B q B y A in which yi is the molar fraction of gas i (i = A and B) in the gas mixture.
elements.clean_text:
Column Breakthrough Experiments

The breakthrough curves were recorded on a home-built setup equipped with a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer GSD320). The breakthrough experiments for the C2H6/C2H4 (50/50, v/v) mixture were carried out at a flow rate of 2 mL/min (298 K, 1 bar). An activated BIF-108-Zn powder sample (510 mg) was packed into a custom-made stainless-steel column (3.0 mm I.D. × 120 mm) under a pure He atmosphere. The flow rates of all gas mixtures were regulated by mass flow controllers. The outlet gas from the column was monitored by a mass spectrometer. Prior to breakthrough experiments, the sample was activated in situ in the adsorption bed with a vacuum pump for 12 h at 333 K. After the breakthrough experiment, the sample was regenerated in situ in the column for 12 h at 373 K. The complete breakthrough of C2H6 was determined using downstream gas composition reaching that of the feed gas. On the basis of the mass balance, the gas adsorption capacities can be determined from the following equation:       q   i   =     C   i   V   22.4 m   ×   ∫   o   t    ( 1 -   F     F   0     )  d t   where qi  is the equilibrium adsorption capacity of gas i (mmol/g), Ci  is the feed gas concentration, V is the volumetric feed flow rate (cm3/min), t is the adsorption time (min), F 0 and F refer to the inlet and outlet gas molar flow rates, and m refers to the adsorbent mass (g). The separation factor (α) of breakthrough experiments was calculated as follows:    α =     q   A     y   B       q   B     y   A       in which yi  is the molar fraction of gas i (i = A and B) in the gas mixture.

elements.content:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c03620.

Crystallographic information on BIF-108-Zn (CIF)

Reagent and instrumentation, single-crystal X-ray crystallography, crystallography data, topology of BIF-108-Zn, powder X-ray diffraction patterns, thermogravimetric analysis plot, variable-temperature-dependent PXRD patterns, gas adsorption tests, in situ Fourier transform infrared spectra, and summary of the adsorption capacity and productivity (PDF)

cln_elements.content: The mixture of KBH­(2-mim)3 (0.043 g), 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (0.042 g), and zinc acetate­(0.080 g), in a water (H2O, 1 mL)/isopropyl alcohol (2 mL)/dimethylformamide (DMF, 2 mL) solution, was placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with ethanol and distilled water, the colorless crystals were obtained.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of the BIF-108-Zn Crystal

The mixture of KBH(2-mim)3 (0.043 g), 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (0.042 g), and zinc acetate(0.080 g), in a water (H2O, 1 mL)/isopropyl alcohol (2 mL)/dimethylformamide (DMF, 2 mL) solution, was placed in a 20 mL vial. The sample was heated at 80 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with ethanol and distilled water, the colorless crystals were obtained.

cln_elements.content:
Separation of ethylene (C2H4) from ethane (C2H6) through one step is desirable but challenging in view of their similar sizes and physical properties. Introduction of pore partition agents into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) endows materials with multivariate porous environments for gas adsorption and separation. Here, we report a novel microporous boron imidazolate framework (BIF-108-Zn) that integrates both organic ligands and extra-framework species as pore partition agents to divide the interconnected channels into isolated cages. This structure possesses a high pore volume with a reduced pore size and a functionalized pore surface to realize preferential binding of C2H6 over C2H4. Dynamic breakthrough measurements demonstrated that BIF-108-Zn can directly produce polymer-grade C2H4 with a productivity of 0.69 mmol/g at 298 K and 1 bar from a binary mixture of C2H6/C2H4. Furthermore, the relatively low isosteric enthalpy value endows it with good regenerability and high stability, as verified by multiple adsorption separation tests.

To investigate the permanent porosity of BIF-108-Zn, the as-synthesized samples were activated by solvent exchange in ethanol for a week and then degassed at 80 °C under high vacuum prior to the measurement. The N2 sorption measurements at 77 K showed a type-I adsorption isotherm behavior with a maximum uptake of 255 cm3/g, which is characteristic of microporous materials and consistent with the crystal structure (c). The corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of BIF-108-Zn were 708 m2/g and 0.39 cm3/g, respectively. The pore size distribution derived from the NLDFT model-based analysis upon the corresponding N2 sorption isotherms gave the peak position at 6.4 Å, which is close to the data from the crystal structure. Moreover, the CO2 isotherms were measured up to 1 bar at different temperatures. BIF-108-Zn exhibited reversible CO2 adsorption with uptake values of 87.0 cm3/g (3.8 mmol/g) at 273 K and 64.4 cm3/g (2.9 mmol/g) at 298 K (d), which are comparable to some of the best performing metal–azolate frameworks (e.g., 5A@ZIF-8, 3.0 mmol/g; MAF-23, 3.3 mmol/g; MAF-25, 5.2 mmol/g; MAF-26, 3.8 mmol/g). From the above results, it can be concluded that the pore space of BIF-108-Zn can be finely tuned through a soft–robust combination pore space partition strategy, leading to a high pore volume with a small pore size.

The permanent microporosity and desirable pore size motivated us to explore its utility as an adsorbent for C2H6/C2H4 separation. Single-component adsorption isotherms for C2H6 and C2H4 were measured at 273 and 298 K, and both reveal type-I isotherms (a). The adsorption amount of C2H6 (78.7 cm3/g) was lower than that of C2H4 (88.6 cm3/g) at 1 bar and 273 K, whereas at 298 K, the uptakes were almost the same (62.7 cm3/g for C2H6 and 61.6 cm3/g for C2H4). More importantly, the uptake isotherm of C2H6 revealed a steeper slope than that of C2H4 under low pressures (b), indicating the preference of BIF-108-Zn for C2H6 over C2H4. The unique adsorption characteristic can be explained by the window size and the charged microporous environment of the cage. Furthermore, the isosteric enthalpies (Q st) of adsorption were calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation, giving 22.5 kJ/mol for C2H6 at zero coverage, slightly higher than the value of 21.2 kJ/mol for C2H4 (Figures S5–S7). Q st values were in agreement with the sorption isotherms. Note that a relatively low isosteric enthalpy value means a relatively low energy consumption for absorbent regeneration. The above results suggested that BIF-108-Zn might be a potential candidate for the separation of C2H6 and C2H4. To estimate the adsorption selectivity, the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) was employed from single-component experimental adsorption isotherms (c and Figures S8 and S9). The selectivity value of C2H6 over C2H4 was 1.37 for a binary gas mixture (50:50 v/v) at room temperature and 100 kPa, which is lower than that of Fe2(O2)­(dobdc) (4.4) while being comparable with other reported classic materials (NPU-1/2/3 (1.32/1.52/3.21), UiO-66 (1.8), IRMOF-8 (1.8), and UTSA-35 (1.4)).

To evaluate the actual separation ability, dynamic adsorption breakthrough experiments were also carried out in a packed column of the activated BIF-108-Zn for C2H6/C2H4 (50/50, v/v) binary mixtures. The breakthrough data reveal that the complete separation of C2H6 from C2H4 can be effectively achieved by BIF-108-Zn under ambient conditions. C2H4 first broke through the adsorption bed at ca. 45 min, to give a desirable polymer-grade (>99.9%) C2H4 at the outlet (d). After a certain time, C2H6 broke through the column, and the outlet gas stream reached the equilibrium. According to the breakthrough data, the adsorption capacity of pure C2H4 in BIF-108-Zn during the breakthrough process was calculated to be 0.69 mmol/g, which is comparable with some reported excellent materials (Fe2(O2)­(dobdc), 0.79 mmol/g; MAF-49, 0.28 mmol/g; Azole-Th-1, 0.68 mmol/g, Table S2). Meanwhile, the selectivity was calculated to be 1.21, indicating a moderate separation ability under dynamic separation conditions. Furthermore, three cycle breakthrough experiments were conducted under the same conditions to test the recyclability of BIF-108-Zn (e). The breakthrough time interval remained almost unchanged, meaning no noticeable loss in the separation capacity. In addition, the PXRD pattern of our sample collected after the breakthrough experiments was also consistent with the PXRD pattern before the breakthrough (Figure S10), which further verified its good regenerability and high stability. To understand the origin of the selective adsorption to C2H6 over C2H4, in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) studies were carried out by exposing the activated BIF-108-Zn to C2H6 and C2H4. The FTIR spectrum of BIF-108-Zn exhibited strong peaks at 2950 and 2888 cm–1 in an C2H6 atmosphere (Figure S11) and 3100 and 2987 cm–1 in an C2H4 atmosphere (Figure S12), which are assigned to gaseous or physisorbed C2H6 and C2H4, respectively. Notably, two new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm–1 appeared when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H6 atmosphere, and their intensity increased with an increase in the C2H6 concentration (f). However, new peaks were difficult to detect when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H4 atmosphere. The emergence of new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm–1 was attributed to the enhanced intermolecular interactions among the adsorbates (C2H6) and the weak van der Waals interactions between adsorbates and the framework of BIF-108-Zn. These observations demonstrated that the reduced pore size and the charged pore environment in BIF-108-Zn contribute to enhanced confinement effects and multisite adsorption for C2H6.

However, new peaks were difficult to detect when BIF-108-Zn was exposed to an C2H4 atmosphere. The emergence of new peaks at 2773 and 2751 cm-1 was attributed to the enhanced intermolecular interactions among the adsorbates (C2H6) and the weak van der Waals interactions between adsorbates and the framework of BIF-108-Zn. These observations demonstrated that the reduced pore size and the charged pore environment in BIF-108-Zn contribute to enhanced confinement effects and multisite adsorption for C2H6.

Imidazolate Framework for Ethylene Separation
